Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Educating and the Interface: Nanomaterial Environmental Impacts and Policy (EI-NEIP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award creates a new interdisciplinary graduate training program whose focus is nanotechnology, its environmental effects, and policy at Carnegie Mellon and Howard University, in collaboration with the Center for Environmental Implications of Nanotechnology.

This program will operate at the interface of science and environmental policy and will produce an environmentally- and policy-literate generation of nanoscience professionals with the skills needed to assess and manage environmental risks associated with nanomaterials. The program's goal is to foster the creation of knowledge and the exchange of ideas within an innovative and stimulating educational experience that will advance not only our knowledge of nanoparticles in the environment but also our understanding of how best to avoid their potential negative consequences. Broader impacts include the training of interdisciplinary Ph.D.-level scientists and engineers who, in addition to receiving rigorous scientific training, will have an understanding of the principles of good environmental stewardship, societal concerns as they relate to nanotechnology, and will be prepared to take leadership roles in dealing with environmental risk. Graduate students from multiple disciplines will participate in this two-year training program where they will learn the fundamentals of their core discipline and gain proficiency in the analysis of environmental issues pertaining to nanotechnology, decision science, and policy analysis, in new nanotechnology-themed courses. To promote interdisciplinary research students will be advised by at least two faculty members from different academic disciplines and will participate in laboratory exchanges with international partners.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Nanotechnology Environmental Effects and Policy (NEEP) IGERT project provided education and research experiences for 22 trainees over seven years.  IGERT trainees, along with their advisors and co-advisors, produced 31 peer-reviewed publications during the project, and gave 50 poster and oral conference presentations. These projects were highly interdisciplinary and most of the published papers are collaborative efforts with multiple IGERT trainees and PIs contributing to those papers. Many of the papers would not have been possible without close collaboration between the Trainees and the access to international collaborations. The major accomplishments can be categorized in several areas including 1) fundamental polymer-nanoparticle interactions, 2) transformations of nanomaterials in the environment, 3) nano-bio interactions, and 4) modeling of nanomaterial fate in the environment.

The research of several IGERT trainees increased our understanding of the interactions and physico-chemical characteristics of polymer-grafted nanoparticle materials. This understanding was used to better control the interactions and assembly of nanoparticles also as functional building blocks of nanocomposite materials for application in active self-regulating membrane materials. IGERT trainees also conducted fundamental work elucidating the role of polymeric ligands on the interactions between bio-derived nanoparticle systems. This understanding of the strength of interaction of the NPs in polymeric matrices was important in one of the IGERT capstone projects, where IGERT trainees developed a tiered strategy to determine the potential for release of NPs from consumer products containing NPs in polymeric matrices.

Many of the IGERT trainees’ research was focused on understanding the transformations of NPs in environmental and biological matrices, and determining the impact of these transformations on their potential risks. A consistent theme resulting from our IGERT research was that the fate of engineered nanomaterials is determined in a large part by the environmental properties (e.g. redox state, amount of organic matter, etc.). In many cases, the impact of the various environmental properties is more important to consider than the specific nanomaterial properties (e.g. polymeric surface coatings). The understanding developed on this project will enable the nanotechnology research community to better prioritize research aimed at predicting the effects that nanomaterials may have on the environment, and can inform manufacturers of NPs about desirable and undesirable properties in the materials from the point of view of environmental health and safety. 

Many of our IGERT trainees were fortunate enough to work with an interdisciplinary group of ecologists, toxicologists, materials scientists, and chemists, to probe the fundamental physical and biological processes affecting the fate of NPs in freshwater systems.  This included laboratory experiments with bacteria and aquatic and terrestrial plants, as well as conducting experiments in one of a kind wetland freshwater mesocosms. Interdisciplinary research by IGERT trainees has greatly improved our understanding of how bacteria respond to the presence of NPs, including effects on quorum sensing (QS) and their metagenomics responses to exposures to NPs. The discoveries underlying the properties of NPs and how they change and interact with biological systems has led to new lines of research focused on developing new applications of NPs (e.g., in electrochemical energy storage).  

The development of models of environmental fate are a culmination of efforts between IGERT trainees.  This is because the model development requires a fundamental understanding of NP behaviors as well as the data needed to parameterize those models. Including geochemical transformations significantly improved the accuracy of the risk assessment model.

Overall, the highly interdisciplinary work of the IGERT trainees has led to novel understanding of the fate and behavior of NPs in natural and biological systems, important transformations, and elucidated NP-biological interactions. 


Last Modified: 05/11/2018
Modified by: Jeanne M Vanbriesen

This understanding of the strength of interaction of the NPs in polymeric matrices was important in one of the IGERT capstone projects, where IGERT trainees developed a tiered strategy to determine the potential for release of NPs from consumer products containing NPs in polymeric matrices.
